title: Walter Burke
text:
Walter Lawrence Burke (August 25, 1908 – August 4, 1984) was an American <a href="character%20actor">character actor</a> of stage, film, and television whose career in entertainment spanned over a half century. Although he was a native of New York, Burke's <a href="Ireland">Irish</a> ancestry often led to his being cast in roles as an Irishman or Englishman. His small stature and distinctive voice and face also made him easily recognizable to audiences even when he was performing in minor supporting roles.
Early life and stage career.
Walter Burke was born in the <a href="Brooklyn%2C%20New%20York">Brooklyn</a> <a href="borough">borough</a> of <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> to Irish immigrant parents Bedelia (<a href="n%C3%A9e">née</a> McNamara) and Thomas Burke. He had one brother and two sisters. His father bred trotting horses, with one farm each in Ireland and Scotland.
Burke began acting on stage as a teenager, making his <a href="Broadway%20%28theatre%29">Broadway</a> debut in "<a href="Dearest%20Enemy">Dearest Enemy</a>" at the <a href="Knickerbocker%20Theatre%20%28Broadway%29">Knickerbocker Theatre</a> during the 1925–1926 season. The following year he performed in the musical revue "Padlocks of 1927" at the <a href="Shubert%20Theatre%20%28Broadway%29">Shubert Theatre</a>. He then joined the <a href="American%20Opera%20Company">American Opera Company</a>'s troupe in January 1928, performing a non-singing role in an English-language adaption of "<a href="Faust%20%28opera%29">Faust</a>". He continued with that company through January 1930, taking part in adaptions of "<a href="Madame%20Butterfly">Madame Butterfly</a>" and "Yolanda of Cyprus" at the <a href="Casino%20Theatre%20%28Broadway%29">Casino Theatre</a>. His other Broadway credits included "<a href="Help%20Yourself%21">Help Yourself!</a>" (1936), "<a href="Red%20Harvest%20%28play%29">Red Harvest</a>" (1937), "A Hero Is Born" (1937), "The Old Foolishness" (1940), "<a href="Under%20This%20Roof">Under This Roof</a>" (1942), "<a href="The%20Eve%20of%20St.%20Mark">The Eve of St. Mark</a>" (1942-1943), "<a href="The%20World%27s%20Full%20of%20Girls">The World's Full of Girls</a>" (1943), "<a href="Sadie%20Thompson%20%28musical%29">Sadie Thompson</a>" (1944-1945), "<a href="Up%20in%20Central%20Park">Up in Central Park</a>" (1945-1947), "<a href="Billy%20Budd%20%28play%29">Billy Budd</a>" (1951), "<a href="Three%20Wishes%20for%20Jamie">Three Wishes for Jamie</a>" (1952), and "<a href="Major%20Barbara">Major Barbara</a>" (1957).
Film.
Burke debuted in <a href="Hollywood">Hollywood</a> films in <a href="1948%20in%20film">1948</a>, with "<a href="The%20Naked%20City">The Naked City</a>", and the following year had a memorable role in the <a href="Academy%20Awards">Oscar-winning</a> film "<a href="All%20the%20King%27s%20Men%20%281949%20film%29">All the King's Men</a>". Burke would appear in twenty-two more films, and three more Broadway productions, but both film and the stage would soon take a backseat to his television work.
Television.
In 1951, Burke played a jockey in the early television series "<a href="Martin%20Kane%2C%20Private%20Eye">Martin Kane</a>". From then until 1980, he would appear in episodes of 103 different television series, as well as three made-for-television movies. Though never a series regular, he often played different roles in multiple episodes of the same shows. In 1959–60, he appeared five times as Tim Potter in the <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a> <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> <a href="television%20series">series</a> "<a href="Black%20Saddle">Black Saddle</a>" starring <a href="Peter%20Breck">Peter Breck</a>. That same season, he appeared on <a href="Andrew%20Duggan">Andrew Duggan</a>'s "<a href="Bourbon%20Street%20Beat">Bourbon Street Beat</a>" and <a href="John%20Cassavetes">John Cassavetes</a>'s "<a href="Johnny%20Staccato">Johnny Staccato</a>" detective series. He portrayed defendant Freddie Green in <a href="Columbia%20Broadcasting%20System">CBS</a>'s "<a href="Perry%20Mason%20%281957%20TV%20series%29">Perry Mason</a>" in the 1959 episode, "The Case of the Jaded Joker," the first of five appearances in diverse roles.
In 1960 he played prosecutor James Blackburn in "The Case of the Ominous Outcast." Among his other roles he played a panhandler and a private detective. He guest-starred as Hatfield in the 1961 episode "The Drought" of the <a href="Television%20syndication">syndicated</a> western series "<a href="Two%20Faces%20West">Two Faces West</a>". In the 1962–1963 season, he appeared on the CBS <a href="anthology%20series">anthology series</a> "<a href="The%20Lloyd%20Bridges%20Show">The Lloyd Bridges Show</a>". In the 1965–1966 season, Burke appeared on another ABC western, "<a href="The%20Legend%20of%20Jesse%20James%20%28TV%20series%29">The Legend of Jesse James</a>". Burke played a magician called "Zeno the Great" in a 1965 (first season) episode of "<a href="Bewitched">Bewitched</a>" entitled "It's Magic". Burke also appeared on an episode of "<a href="Lost%20in%20Space">Lost in Space</a>", playing Mr. O.M. in "The Toymaker" (1967). He also appeared in an episode of "Wild Wild West" as the mayor of a town under siege, in "<a href="Hogan%27s%20Heroes">Hogan's Heroes</a>" as the master safe cracker Alfie the Artiste, and in two episodes of "Bonanza", as Jesse in "Destiny's Child", and as an unsuspecting witness in a trial. Burke performed as well in the Western series "<a href="The%20Virginian%20%28TV%20series%29">The Virginian</a>", portraying the character Billy Neal in the 1970 episode "The Gift".
Personal life.
Burke married Kathryn Patricia Rooney in 1937 and they had four children, Catherine, Margaret, Deborah and Leslie. Kathryn Rooney died by suicide on May 21, 1956, after shooting herself with a .32 special rifle in the family's Henryville, Pennsylvania, home while her husband was working in New York.
Burke split most of his later life between <a href="Hollywood">Hollywood</a>, where he worked, and his farm in <a href="Monroe%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Monroe County, Pennsylvania</a>. While back east, he would sometimes teach dramatics at a local college.
Death.
On August 4, 1984, Burke died from <a href="emphysema">emphysema</a> while living at the <a href="Motion%20Picture%20%26amp%3B%20Television%20Country%20House%20and%20Hospital">Motion Picture & Television Country House and Hospital</a> in <a href="Woodland%20Hills%2C%20Los%20Angeles">Woodland Hills, California</a>.
